'Shoulder dystocia' is a specific case of dystocia whereby after the delivery of
the head, the anterior shoulder of the infant cannot pass below the pubic
symphysis, or requires significant manipulation to pass below the pubic
symphysis. It is diagnosed when the shoulders fail to deliver shortly after the
fetal head. In shoulder dystocia, it is the chin that presses against the walls
of the perineum. Shoulder dystocia is an obstetric emergency, and fetal demise
can occur if the infant is not delivered, due to compression of the umbilical
cord within the birth canal.
